org.gwtunite.client.file
Class FileSystem

java.lang.Object
  com.google.gwt.core.client.JavaScriptObject
      org.gwtunite.client.file.FileSystem

public final class FileSystem
extends com.google.gwt.core.client.JavaScriptObject

Virtual file system implementation

The FileSystem class represents a virtual file system. Actual files are connected to it by defining mount points from the actual file system. This way file system access can be limited to a selected set of files rather than allow unsecure operations on the local file system directly.

Path references in the virtual file systems always use '/' as the path separator.

In order to retrieve an instance of this class, use the getInstance() method NOTE: Currently ONLY methods that are supported by Opera Unite are implemented

isFeatureInstalled

public static boolean isFeatureInstalled()
Returns true if the FileSytem feature is installed

getInstance

public static FileSystem getInstance()
Retrieve an instance of the VirtualFileSystem

Returns:
an instance of the VirtualFileSystem
Throws:
FeatureUnavailableException - if the filesystem feature has not been specified in the applications config.xml

getMountPoints

public File getMountPoints()
The mount points currently attached to this FileSystem

This is a special File object that represents the root of the virtual file system and serves to enumerate the existing mount points. Its path is / and its name is empty. If you mount a directory as foo, the path of the mount point is /foo.

To see all the mount points use File.listFiles()

Returns:
a virtual directory containing all current mount points

mountApplicationFileSystem

public File mountApplicationFileSystem()
Mount the Application system directory.

The application directory contains the actual files and directories of the current application accessing the API. For widgets, for example, the config.xml and index.html and other files of the widget are found here. This directory is mounted as readonly.

These directories of the application are not mounted by default. You need to call this method to mount and use them. Once mounted, they are available through the mountPoints property like other mount points. Files and directories under them can be accessed by resolving and using the mountpoint URL protocol as for normal files.

Returns:
File object representing the mounted Application directory

mountApplicationFileSystemAs

public File mountApplicationFileSystemAs(java.lang.String name)
Mount the Application system directory.

The application directory contains the actual files and directories of the current application accessing the API. For widgets, for example, the config.xml and index.html and other files of the widget are found here. This directory is mounted as readonly.

These directories of the application are not mounted by default. You need to call this method to mount and use them. Once mounted, they are available through the mountPoints property like other mount points. Files and directories under them can be accessed by resolving and using the mountpoint URL protocol as for normal files.

Parameters:
name - The name the mount point should be known as
Returns:
File object representing the mounted Application directory

mountSharedFileSystem

public File mountSharedFileSystem()
Mount the shared system directory.

The shared directory is for sharing data from the regular file system. The directory is typically selected by the user when installing the application.

This directory is mounted as read-write unless the underlying file system defines it to be read-only. You should take care to protect your data by limiting access and checking for exploitable code.

Returns:
File object representing the shared system directory

mountSharedFileSystemAs

public File mountSharedFileSystemAs(java.lang.String name)
Mount the shared system directory.

The shared directory is for sharing data from the regular file system. The directory is typically selected by the user when installing the application.

This directory is mounted as read-write unless the underlying file system defines it to be read-only. You should take care to protect your data by limiting access and checking for exploitable code.

Parameters:
name - The name by which the mount point will be known
Returns:
File object representing the shared system directory

mountStorageFileSystem

public File mountStorageFileSystem()
Mount the storage system directory.

The storage directory is for storing temporary files and configuration files specific to the service, for example uploaded files. This directory and its contents are persisted until the application is uninstalled.

Returns:
File object representing the mounted storage directory

mountStorageFileSystemAs

public File mountStorageFileSystemAs(java.lang.String name)
Mount the storage system directory.

The storage directory is for storing temporary files and configuration files specific to the service, for example uploaded files. This directory and its contents are persisted until the application is uninstalled.

Parameters:
name - The name by which the mount point will be known
Returns:
File object representing the mounted storage directory

removeMountPoint

public void removeMountPoint(java.lang.String mountPoint)
                      throws IOException
Remove the given mount point. Removes a mount point from the virtual file system, either by referencing its symbolic name or by passing a File object representing the mount point. If the mount point is mounted as persistent, removing it will also remove the persistence.

Parameters:
mountPoint - File object representing the mount point or a String with the name of the mount point.
Throws:
IOException - If the given File or String doesn't represent a mount point.
